block.p: Harold Reynolds went to work yesterday as an analyst for MLB.com, almost 11 months after being fired by ESPN in a disputed sexual-harassment case. He is suing ESPN for wrongful termination and damages.

Harold Reynolds went to work yesterday as an analyst for MLB.com, almost 11 months after being fired by ESPN in a disputed sexual-harassment case. He is suing ESPN for wrongful termination and damages.
Reynolds, 46, will work intermittently for MLB.com until the All-Star Game, after which he will have a 15-minute afternoon program Mondays through Fridays.
''I think this is just the beginning,'' he said by telephone after his one-hour debut, in which he took questions from fans.
Reynolds said he had had early talks about joining the MLB Channel when it starts operations in 2009, but that is not part of his contract.
The months since his dismissal by ESPN have been difficult, he said, ''but I've got a tremendous wife who's shown great strength through this.''

ESPN fired him four months into a six-year contract that was to pay him at least $4.9 million; it later said in a state court filing that five young women had lodged ''concerns'' about Reynolds's sexual misconduct.
Last month, a judge in Hartford ordered ESPN to give Reynolds his personnel file; the contents, he said, ''made my case stronger.''

''It had what they claimed was in there,'' he said, referring to ESPN officials, ''but for the first time I saw what they were going on, and I felt like their stories were misrepresented. It's kind of sad.''
Reynolds said ESPN executives never asked him about the accusations before he was dismissed after 11 years at the network. He was an analyst on ''Baseball Tonight.''
He added, ''This isn't about flowers, gifts, cards, lewd jokes, not any of that stuff, because that's not my behavior,'' but a misunderstanding over buying a meal for a woman who was an intern.

Reynolds began to talk to baseball officials this year. In a meeting with Bob DuPuy, baseball's chief operating officer, he said, ''I was totally open and transparent and assured him that I didn't feel like I had done anything wrong and that I won't embarrass you.''
Reynolds then met with Bob Bowman, the president of MLB Advanced Media, which owns MLB.com.
''Harold has a great reputation as a baseball analyst, and we felt comfortable with that,'' Bowman said. ''We asked about his situation, he addressed our questions and we were satisfied.''
Reynolds, a former Seattle Mariners second baseman, said he had been spending much of his time with his 13-month-old daughter, his first child.
He said he also had been discussing baseball with a group of older men over coffee at a deli near his home in West Hartford, Conn.
''They've kept me sharp,'' he said.
